values:
I can hardly believe that after 3 years, it's only 2 weeks until my sweetie,
shaka_sulu
, embarks on his trek to join me in Florida and less than a hundred days til our wedding! I am not embarrassed to say I am nesting like an insane person and only semi-neglecting a few details in my delerium. Soon, I'll catch up on the blogging, I swear. Since his office only just found out after our annual conference a couple of weeks ago (and the ensuing horror on the way back that is flight cancellation, more on that later), I haven't even updated my own site.

Now, it's all just around the corner, and I've only woken up a few times in the last week going... HOLY COW!!!! But, you know, I'm not worried about the wedding and marriage at all, because I have sage advice like this. The bogus 50s bargraphs and Graph O' Compatibility were worth 16 sessions of counseling at least. heh heh 

Are You Ready for Marriage? MST3K style:

Space shuttle
Originally uploaded by sdpalladio
My family and I drove out to NASA on Saturday to see the shuttle go up. Perfect launch day, but a real scorcher. Lots of astronauts wandering around, and we had tickets for "lunch with an astronaut" who was Jon McBride. He couldn't have been nicer to the crowd, mostly full of little ones too young to understand, and we got a photo with him afterwards. He seemed unusally tall for a former test pilot (usually you can spot them a mile away), but he was very dynamic.

Video of Hail at Town Center
Originally uploaded by sdpalladio
Sunday afternoon, I'd run to Ann Taylor to try on some dresses and saw a huge, low-hanging black cloud. As soon as I stepped inside the dressing room, the storm started and I could tell it was probably hailing. Sure enough, one of the girls runs back to tell us it is and that she'd never seen it before. I took this video through the window while I waited for it to stop for about 20 minutes.

I pulled up to my favorite Starbucks again this morning and I couldn't help but have flashbacks to the whole Giant Spider Event, although one did not run off with my scone this morning. Then I come in to find this on XKCD:

So, I'm not one to pass gossip and hearsay, but... ok, who am I kidding. I totally am. I am a celebrity gossip and spoiler smuthound. There, I said it.

Anyway, I found this totally nonspecific, possibly totally made up, and yet totally must-read piece of gossip on one of the sites I frequent:

These three cast members from Battlestar Galactica all share a home. Nothing wrong with that. Actually there is nothing really wrong with the fact that all three share the same bedroom. Now, the husband of one of the women in the threesome might be a little put out by the living situation, but what he doesn't know won't hurt him.

 

I think my fanfic fandom brain just exploded.

So, I have the BSG Last Supper photo on my desktop, and as I started to sign off after tonight's ep, I remembered they'd said the picture revealed everything for the final season. Obviously this is in retrospect, and it's probably been said already by someone more astute, but, as a major DaVinci Code fan, I had to post these portions of it:

Six is the sacrificial lamb, with Baltar figuring as John the Beloved, and we see this come to pass at the end of the episode when Athena shoots NatalieSix in cold blood...



Obviously her death changes the whole game, though it doesn't necessarily imply she's the saviour, since the roles are all shuffled throughout the tableau.

The BSG Last Supper is missing a person on the left side, who is interestingly not the Judas figure--Lee has his elbow on the table, the same rude gesture as the original Judas, though he is facing away, rather than having Judas' expression of shock at being found out--but rather Peter. 

Thinking about it now, I suppose that's fairly appropriate, since Peter is the rock the church was built on, and the Final Cylon would be the cornerstone of this whole mystery. However, in the DaVinci conspiracies, Peter's slashing hand gesture towards John/Mary Magdeline and the knife in his other hand is considered part of what reveals the "truth" of the Magdeline story. These symbols aren't missing--Tyrol has the knife, and Athena has the slash (oh, the fanfic):



Tonight's ending is shown by these two gestures: she's grasping Karl's hand to show familial solidarity and slashing with her right hand across the same sight line as Six's exposed wrist, like so:



Incidentally, I got the idea for the overlay from this guy, who makes some very interesting points, but I don't think quite got it. I'll post my whole overlay tomorrow.... after I get some sleep!

So, I pull up in line at the Starbucks this morning to get my Monday morning courage and suddenly, this thing catches my attention--a huge spider is lurching down the building near the car in front of me. The driver looks over and is watching it with huge eyes, leaned away from his window. I stare at it, mouth agape. I see the people behind me pointing, incredulous.

The car pulls up, and I'm next to it now, and it is at least the size of my fist, if not more. At one point, it runs down to the sidewalk and towards my car, so I think it must be making a break for the bushes on the other side of the driveway. Hoping I don't run over it, I pull forward.

My window keeps getting stuck down lately, so I pull up to the window and open my door to hand the girl my card. Next thing I know, there the spider is, about a foot away from the window! So I say to her, "Um, you might wanna close your window a minute, because there is a HUGE spider out here." Of course, nobody really understands what you mean by huge until they look themselves, so she pokes her head out and screams, running into the center of her spot, away from the open window. Each barista takes a turn at the window, looking and squealing, and of course the whole line of cars is full of people pointing and covering their mouths.

At this point, we're all a little hysterical with laughter and creepiness, and as she finishes my order, the spider comes EVEN CLOSER, all the way to the edge of the window, with me going, "UM!!! UM!!! SOMEONE SHOULD CLOSE THE WINDOW!!!!"

The barista looks at me and says, "Are you ready?" So I say, "Yes!" and she tosses my drink and scone to me and I speed off. $10 bucks says the thing made it inside. I'm pretty sure it was a male wolf spider.

You know you want to see:

We just opened our new hospital on campus, and there are a lot of new people around. My office is at the end of a very long, convoluted hallway, and you can't accidentally get there. It's like 4:45, and the head of the new ER walks in to "introduce himself to the neighbors," which originally really confused us because the ER is nowhere near here. We cracked ourselves up with picturing him walking down the long, long hallway, randomly walking into offices and shaking hands like a politician.

Today we figured out that his private office is on the hallway, so that makes more sense. I'd actually met him several times before, but I let that slide since I'm sure he meets a lot of people every day.

Anyway, he starts saying how he and some other doctors just started a new Emergency Medicine journal, and I say that's wonderful, and that I know the staff of the main EM journal, which I'm sure he reads because published by their main association, so I'm familiar with the issues they might run into. But he looks at me blankly and says, "No, this is a new journal."

So I try to explain for him, "Yes, but I mean, I know the journal staff of JAEM. They're very nice." And he keeps looking at me kind of spacey, and says, "They don't work on this. This is the journal we just started."

There was a beat where Robin looked at me and started to jump in there to clarify, and I just gave him my best Bless His Heart smile, wished him luck, and said we were available for any related journal questions he might have.

Doctors. You gotta love 'em.

What a weekend! I ate at my two favorite places ever while visiting my brother in Orlando to attend a yoga seminar. His 28th birthday was last Wednesday, so I went a bit early. Friday night we hit Seasons 52, and if you're ever in a city that has one, YOU MUST GO. The one in Orlando is fantastic, right on a lake. It had been 80 degrees, so we took patio seating as the sun set over the lake and ordered mojitos--they make the best ones. Their theme is to change the menu with the season for the freshest food, and change the specials by the week so there's always something new. All the food is under 500 calories, and I've never had anything I didn't like there. Carmelized scallops, sun-dried tomato pearl pasta, and asparagus. Hello! With one of those shotglass-full desserts of chocolate and peanut butter mousse. If you want to know who started that trend, it was them.

We stayed up way too late every night talking about his new job with the space program, and I feel very educated now on the whole thing. I also discovered one of my personal pet peeves: unfinished roads with turnoffs to nowhere. You know what I mean--you can SEE where you want to go, but the road isn't done? He was showing me the Google map of NASA and pointed out where the road to the original Launch Pad A should have been (the one they use most often is called Launch Pad A, but was really Launch Pad C). It just ends in the forest. Did you know they'd originally planned to have launch pads all over the coastline and send up a shuttle every week? Only 2 were built, but they're thinking of finishing the 3rd. Not seriously, really, but it comes up. And, so, I am personally starting the I SUPPORT LAUNCH PAD C campaign just so they'll finish the road :D

During our lunch break on Sunday, I spotted something that made my heart glad: bd's Mongolian Grill. I'd been to the one in Traverse City several years ago and had a blast, but there were none in Florida. I even tried convincing one of my friends who wanted to buy a franchise to bring them down, but no luck. 3 years later, HOORAY. Joshua met me there after yoga and we celebrated with a margarita (that's my post-yoga celebratory restaurant rule) and ridiculous amounts of stir fry.

Somehow I don't think celebrating my own bday in Jax with my parents this weekend will be quite that fun, but it was a nice break. 

Yoga training went well. I surprised myself with how shakey I felt during our first class, but now I think it was related to not eating lunch first! Duh! When it's at that facility, it starts at a weird time, so it never occurs to me to get food before I'm stuck in class. Most of the material not related to poses was about communication--with yourself and with your class. Timely and helpful. It was my favorite instructor, and she keeps things from getting too weird or burdensome. Good group, good class, but I'm glad to be done. Feels like I'm finally starting to make progress on my training, and I'm subbing in for classes the next two Thursdays.

In other news, sorry I haven't been around much on LJ. Just been absorbed in other things. But I still love you! ;-)

The Water Horse is a Gossip
Originally uploaded by sdpalladio
In honor of the DVD release of The Water Horse. I didn't see it, because I am anti-animal movies (translation: they make me cry like a baby), but that didn't stop me from horsing around.

Get it?! har har har

For some reason, in the last few weeks, my days have consisted of sitting down at the computer and dazing off, punctuated by bits of work. It certainly hasn't been a creative spell for me. I blame BSG withdrawals. Luckily tomorrow is finally SCIFI FRIDAY, the best day of all good days.  BSG premiere, Torchwood finale, sigh. I will be in heaven... sad heaven, because it's the finale, but hey... SPIKE... on TORCHWOOD. The only way the evening could get better is if David Boreanaz somehow showed up and bit people.

*dazes off again*

So, I've been remiss. Stuff I've been doing:

* Went outside yesterday to call Hawaii re: honeymoon, left watch on bench in prevention of tanline effort, lost watch to roving patients. 
shakasulu
is pleased at the loss of "Stabby Watch"--2 links were held together via beading wire that occasionally doubles as a weapon against salacious hand-holding. Nevertheless, am now watch-less, which is not nearly as good as being timeless or ageless.
* Working, but not particularly hard.
* Reading an ungodly amount of gossip on Jezebel. 
* Completed my DVD-R collection of Angel. Thank you, Lords of Kobol, for Tivo.
* Gazing upon an unfortunate number of little orange flags strewn about the gorgeous lawn in front of my office window, denoting a slew of impending sidewalks to be plowed through said gorgeosity and several lovely trees, prior to them stealing our office for the amusement of the clinic's doctors, who want a new break room. 
* Dug up 2 seedlings from said trees, including one I buried my beloved office fish Lucky underneath, to carry with me to future home.
* Speaking of fish, lost my poor bettagrrl Lolly to some horrible random infection, buried her in my peace lily.
* Dove back into yoga philosophy books in preparation for next training in a week. Spirit is in the universe. Spirit is universe. You are in universe. You are Spirit. Spirit is you. Om. etc.
* Began training for training, using new techniques to perfect shoulder stand; am so sore, cannot reach toes.
* Decided on a number of wedding details, to whit: bridesmaid dresses (without the jacket) in "Truffle" (chocolate); photographer (whom I love); DJ (still need to meet); minister (ditto); and website.
* Went to tiny floral market and bought an armload of flowers to help decide what looked best, and also figure out if am florally-DIY-inclined. Jury still pending. Look at the pretty, though:

So, this week: totally pointless.
Stuff accomplished: no.
Weeklong migraine: yes.
Wedding plans made: none.

lolLOST site found: yes

Go there

Gumby School O' Yoga
Originally uploaded by sdpalladio
So, I was bored. Again.

You know, Stargate SG1 missed out by ending so soon: they could have totally rewritten the whole St Patrick story by making it so that the "snakes" he led out of Ireland were really the Goa'ulds. I mean, they made Merlin and Morgan le Fay into Ancients, right?  

Right?

I'm sorry, but this episode was Teh Suck. Seriously. 

* Carnies are creepy enough, but now they're...what? Aliens, I assume, but who knows. 
* They were trapped by being filmed originally? Or disappeared because they ran out of work? Or both? 
* The first two can escape off the film as shadows, but the others have to walk out of the middle of the screen in plain sight? 
* They stole people's breath in the past for what reason? To listen to them scream in a bottle? 
* If they were only there to steal people's breaths and the victims still existed, why did the carnival disappear with all the people in the past? 
* One breath actually remained IN the bottle when it was open? 
* What was going on with the puddle of water? It used to be the ocean? An abandoned pool? 
* Why didn't they just GO to the ocean?! It's not like Britain isn't an island. 
* They're "ghost makers" but they keep the ghosts in a box that no one ever sees? How did anyone know about the ghosts then? 
* When the people finally do die, the ghosts don't exist anymore? Isn't that, like, reverse ghost principle?

Furthermore, you can't tell me that Jack happily blew his head off every night just to track down The Night Travelers, and then didn't catch them or even know who they were until now. Because, if everyone in the film walked off the screen into real life except Jack, that means THEY were the Night Travelers, and he worked with them. I guess you could argue that it was 2 carnivals spliced together, but Jack says specifically that he remembers the people on the film. So who are the people that appeared suddenly in the middle of the night and didn't advertise? And if Jack was at that very carnival, how did he miss the fact that the WHOLE THING DISAPPEARED?! Did it disappear because they were aliens, or did it disappear because someone filmed them? Either way, why wasn't he just left standing in the field, because he is clearly not trapped in celluloid.

I'M SO CONFUSED.

This is one of those episodes that just make me feel terrible for the actors that they had to be serious and act out the whole thing when it was forced-excitement plot with zero character development. 

Total. Bollocks.

Of course I hated "Small Worlds" too. If you're a PJ fan, I'm sure you enjoyed both of them, but I am unmovable, so please don't try and convince me otherwise. Meanwhile, I will be mourning that utterly wasted hour of my life.

Here's the new one from Simon Tofield, and it's just as good. Anyone who's had an indoor/outdoor cat can attest to its truthfulness.... Ok, even my inside cat does this if I have the bedroom door closed. He sounds like he's being killed out there, or that the Holy Grail is just inside the door. The only thing this cartoon misses is the violent little paw shove under the door, jiggling it off its frame...

   

In other news, I just heard that Sars, Wing Chun, and Glark are leaving TWOP now that it's been one year since Bravo bought the site. Somehow, I'm not entirely surprised, and somehow, I'm entirely sure it's going to suck.

Now who will kill us where we stand? Who will take care of Tubey?! OH THE TWOPMANITY!!!

*sob*

If you were a big LOST fan in the beginning and couldn't wait to see how it turned out, only to get completely turned off by the stupidness that was the Tailies, the Others, Kate/Sawyer, and every other dumb twist this show has taken, here is a great discussion thread about the potential for greatness arising again via alternate timelines.

Read it and get hopelessly excited, realizing that the writers will probably screw it up again. *SOB*

But seriously, it is a great discussion, and do try to get a few pages in.

This morning, Project Runway had its runway show at Bryant Park. Want to see the collections? You know you do!!!

BPR
and here at Getty
and here at Wire Image

Wow, all 5 designers went?! Before you know it, they'll have the whole crew at Bryant Park as decoys. It's really hard to tell who is in the top 3 and who isn't, unless they didn't actually do a top 3 this time. 

My thoughts on the collections:
* Rami - predictable, although polished as usual. I love that blue color, and I can see an evolution in his work, although I think there is too much evening wear.
* Sweet P - scary clown wear... and what is with the gold buttons?
* Christian - also somewhat predictable with the poofy sleeves, but also incredibly cool. He has the touch. That last look with the feathers is wild, but hypnotic.
* Chris - a little Cruella de Ville, but I LOVE the screen printing and color transitions.
* Jillian - clearly stuck on the dark grey steel and belt look... well made, but I don't see much of an evolution.

PS: TORCHWOOD FIX

She Who Always Stays One Step Ahead of Everyone has just broken my poor musically inclined heart.

Yes, Madonna is working with Justin Timberlake and The Great Homogenizing Satan of Music, Timbaland, in order to freshen up her sound.

How fresh can it get after he's "collaborated" with Justin, Dr Dre, Elton John, Fall Out Boy, Nelly Furtado, One Republic, Bjork and CELINE DION, for God's sake!?!

And, of course, the piece de resistance: It's not even coming out under her name. It's coming out under his. I mean, it's one thing for One Republic to allow that with "Apologize," considering they weren't quite big enough to get it on the radio themselves. But, Madonna? 

Geez, Madge... I mean, just what is going on here... I mean... *wibbles slightly* HOW COULD YOU?!?!?!

*sobs quietly in the corner*

That's it: Something MUST be done about Timbaland. Next thing you know he'll be after Sting, and then I will have to declare war.

Dear lovely F-List people,

If you have been posting regularly on your journal, and have noticed a distinct lack of my commenting, it is not because I no longer love you.

I blame Torchwood. Why, you ask? Because I put a Torchwood lj on my f-list, and let me tell you, I thought the BSG people were prolific! I have been veritably drowning in Torchwood info, yea verily, lo these many weeks, and I can barely find my own f-listers in the avalanche of squee and fanfic porn that is Torchwood fandom.  

I would de-list, but then I'd miss out on important reminders that I should illegally watch it.

If anyone has a suggestion on how to better manage it, let me know.

Love,

Here's another thing to scare the crap out of mistagoalie...

Cold Snap Causes Frozen Iguana Shower

You think it's cold where you are? At least amphibians aren't falling out of your trees!

Speaking of cold, I just got back from New York City for the first time. I'll write more about that when I am coherent again--let's just say my boss is a native and wanted to show me every little thing, on foot, in 2.5 days. Cool, and yet my feet are swollen like a biatch.

Anyway, everyone we met with was like, "Oh, you're from Florida? Cold enough for you? hurhrurhur!!"

Which, yes, it was cold as all hell. But right on the other hand, I left the house at 5 am on Thursday morning and it was 16 degrees. That's right, boys and girls, 16 degrees. So yeah, NYC was cold enough for me, because it was actually warmer. That fact blew a lot of people's minds, including mine.

WTF is up with the weather this year?

I'm celebrating New Year's Eve by unloading my storage closet in the apartment... And for someone who is more or less a total cheapskate when it comes to technology, I am rolling in it. What have I found?

* Approximately 4 bajillion USB cables.

* Adapters for... I have no idea

* My 1995 Hitachi laptop with Windows 95 licenses, adapter, laptop surge protector, etc. What do I do with this, besides tie it to my next hit victim's leg when I kick them off a bridge? I can't even begin to imagine. Seriously, suggestions, even creative ones, are welcome.

* My copy of PageMill 2.0. YAH BABY. There was a day when you would have had to pry that out of my cold, dead hands. Along with Netscape.

* A Zip drive with 2 connector cords, since one of my Zips blew up.

* Palm Pilot m100 with teeny tiny keyboard and BodyGlove case. I think I once messaged Sputnik with it. 

*  Various cable modems, ports, and hubs of previous generations.

I am not too proud to say I took pictures of many of them, sent them to my brother, and asked him what the hell they all were. Not that he was helpful in deciding what to do with them afterwards, but it's a start.

In Gossip News...
Just a special little present, if you are as much of a gossip hound as I am, CrazyDaysandNights, reportedly run by a Hollywood entertainment lawyer, anonymously, is revealing some of his top blind items tonight. There are 5 up so far and I can already say... Hello! Check it, y'all.

Finally...
PLEASE, someone, save me from the boring TV hell that the last two weeks has been. Suck, suck, suck.

To all my LJ and IRL friends. I still have to wrap a few things, and I DID actually mail all those Christmas cards. Family insanity has of course kicked in, but there is a gorgeous, incredible full moon out. Those 2 things may not be mutually exclusive. I hope everyone has a happy, stress-free day tomorrow, and if that's not possible, that everyone just remains out of prison.

To kick it off, here's an even more modern version of my favorite New Christmas song ever, Last Christmas:

 

Love y'all! :D

This? Is just killing me. Because it looks EXACTLY like my parents' cat (and previously my cat) Beau. 



...and the Christmas cards are STILL not done.

22

... STILL not done with Christmas cards. And you can see the kind of effort I'm putting in.

The holidays are always full of extremes, aren't they? It seems like just as you get ready for one thing, the time for that has past and it's on to another thing that you're not ready for. Nothing ever really settles down, and everything conspires to keep it that way. Or something like that. Cases in point:

1. Cards: Doing Christmas cards was the last thing on my list. I was so in the mood to write them last week, but didn't have time. I carried them to work with me and back. Finally, yesterday, I had time. 
  Then I had a brainchild: Hey, some of my relatives have never met Adam, so I should do pictures! I printed out some small ones on the work printer, which is lovely, but then tends to stick to things. 
  Another brainchild: Hey! I should send some to Walgreens from Snapfish! I can pick them up on the way home!
  Phone call, finally, at 9 PM from Walgreens: Sorry, our downloads are taking too long. See you tomorrow. So, I opt back to the printed versions... now I don't have photo corners. Blow the whole thing off til this morning.
  Stopped by Michael's this morning to pick up photo corners....
  Incidentally, have you ever gone in there in a sentimental mood? Particularly into the scrapbooking area? Personally, and on every other day, I feel that scrapbooks are the Great Satan of Modern Womanhood. I see the pictures of mothers and daughters happily bonding over Scrapping, and first of all, if that were my mother and I, one of us would end up dead in a heap of glitter with butterfly-shaped holes punched out of our skin; secondly, I can't imagine spending 4 hours on 5 pages in a scrapbook--photo-fiend that I am, I would still be on my child's 2nd birthday as I sent them off to college; thirdly, the activity perpetuates The Evil that is cutting photographs into little cute shapes, and, since nobody can cut a perfectly even circle, lopsided ones at that. 
  But today, I wander in and am captured by the Shiny that is the Martha Stewart aisle of tissue paper flowers and wedding favors on sale and whatever and I'm like, oohhhhhhhhhhhhhhh... 
  *glazed eyes* 
  *fantasizing about all the little romantic things I could whip up*
  Then it took 6 rows and 15 minutes to find photo corners, and I was back to my cynical, foo-foo paper-and-glue-hating self.
  Anyway, at noon, Walgreens calls and the pictures are done. Glossy, much to my horror, and not cut apart, which means I will get fingerprints all over them. 
  Finally, at 2, I sit down to do them in between editing Moments in Ophthalmic History *snore* and... I cannot think of a word to say to people that doesn't sound completely ridiculous, particularly to the expectant parents on the list. What do you say? Can't wait to hear about the baby eventually coming at some point if you even remember me by then because you're covered in baby drool and the last thing you'll be worrying about is informing your 3rd grade best friend? Nothing sounds right. 

My Christmas cards are doomed, I just know it.

2. Food: Prior to going up north 10 days ago, I resolved to eat healthily, knowing I'd be running about willy-nilly and needed to be well. So, I did--I had salads and veggies and juice and no Starbucks. I felt great.
  Then I went up to visit, and we got engaged and embarked upon our Tour de Family and Friends. At this point my diet turned entirely into champagne and hors d'oeuvres. And the occasional ham and cheese from Dunkin' Donuts. By Sunday morning, my stomach was completely shot. And when I say completely, I mean completely.
  Thanks to that, I was on oatmeal and soup for the remainder of the week, given that my stomach soundly protested against anything that tasted. Dear Tummy, no, I would NOT like to have yet another bowl of plain Farina, even if it WOULD greatly amuse my late grandfather, God rest his soul, that all I can eat is what he ate as breakfast porridge in 1918. Love, Me.
  Then Party Season kicked back up on Friday, and now I have pretty much eaten nothing for 4 days but spiced ham, tiny buns and mustard, and chocolate fudge. And the occasional pear, thanks to a basket from our publisher. Healthy!
  Tomorrow I plan on implementing my Peppermint Mocha Frappuchino-only diet. By Christmas I should have red and green sugar sprinkles floating on the surface of my eyeballs.
  The good news is, I'll have enough preservatives in my system to sit on the shelf without spoiling til May.

3. I had some other point, but I forgot what it is. Maybe I'll remember after finishing this fudge.
My little brother said this reminded him of me. I just can't imagine what he means by that.

I could write a long entry about the wonderful thing that happened last Friday, but instead I'm going to let the pictures speak for themselves...


shakasulu
 and me in the Boston MFA. Hooray!

Hey, peeps! Just realized I should put up my own Holiday Cheer Poll for Christmas/Holiday cards. I have LOTS of extra cards (I'm a card sale hohoho) and I'd love to add you guys to my list... 

<lj-poll-1104480>

Thanksgiving happened so early this year that I could barely bring myself to get into the Christmas shopping mood right afterwards. And I gave myself a pass for a while, thinking it would hit me later,  buying a couple things the day after. Then it hit me on that Saturday: I am going up to Massachusetts this Thursday, and if I don't buy everything for 

and his family (and in the process, everyone else) within a few days, it won't get there on time. His house is now laden with boxes that he is not allowed to open.

And so, I am just now emerging from a week-long haze of Christmas ideas/creation/purchasing/bills, etc., including a long weekend in Orlando with my brother where we hit the Millennia Mall 3 times, Waterford Lakes 2 times, and the new IKEA, which, because it only opened a couple of weeks ago, involves shopping with approximately the entire population of Europe. There should totally be an oasis in every corner, because between the 3 million square feet, cloth fibers, and dry warehouse air, I was in a state of near delerium by the time I hit the bottom floor where you buy everything. Which may be by design, I'm not sure.

As I wandered through the Nouveau Scary Large Candy World of Lights Scents Music Christmasland, two memories from holidays past occurred to me:

1. "That's not from Santa!" - My parents were very religious when I was little, so we did not believe in Santa. Sure, they told me about Santa, and I knew all the stories and carols and whatnot, but I knew who my presents came from. My grandparents compromised by making some tags from "Grandma and Grandpa," some from "Baby Jesus," and some from "Santa and Rudolph." 

I remember one Christmas very clearly where all the grandchildren sat near the tree, tearing through the gifts, where my older cousin said to me, "Look what Santa gave me!" I, being all of probably 5 or 6, pulled the name tag off her gift, held it next to mine, and busted out with the handwriting comparison. "Aimee, THAT's not from Santa. It's Grandma. Her handwriting is exactly the same! Look at the t's! Look at the a's! It's the same pen!!!" If I'd had a chemistry set, God only knows what I would have done to prove it.

I finally realized this weekend, regardless of what I'd been told, I was clearly too much of a nerd to believe there was a Santa, even then. Honestly, I thought Grandma was just being ironic, and cleverly so. It never occurred to me they were trying to fool anyone. Because, by George, the handwriting was the SAME. *puts on black shades*

2. Child of the 80s Flashback - Who else played with Strawberry Shortcake dolls? They all had cute little girl outfits and pets and were scented. My favorite one was Lime Chiffon--not because I was crazy about her look, but because she smelled the best, like vanilla and citrus. I'm not really sure how we all looked, snorting our dolls and whatnot, but I loved that smell.

While shopping for stocking stuffers this weekend, I went into Yankee Candle and was smelling down the wall of votives when my eyes went wide and I grabbed my brother's arm. "OHMYGOD!!! Smell this! This is so familiar!! WHAT. IS. IT?!....... IT'S LIME CHIFFON DOLL!"

He, of course, backed away from the lunacy and took my word for it (they didn't sell scented Legos, I guess), while I purchased a Vanilla Lime votive immediately so that I can continue my doll-sniffing in an adult fashion--by making my whole apartment smell like one.


 =


Incidentally, Hasbro, I am disappointed in you: the new versions of Strawberry Shortcake Kids look like Jon-Benet Ramsey's, not freckly munchkin toddlers. For shame!

Christmas Shopping dilemma #1

Create my own line:



So here it is... The Sarahphrase Cafe Press store! Tell me what you think! More snarky items soon to come.

PS Did you know Rosie the Riveter is public domain? Educational moment of the day.

Of course it was great to have BSG back for the night--the poundy drums, the rebooted count on the White Board of Extinction (my favorite character), etc. I thought the battle scenes all looked great, and the panning of Pegasus in dry dock was beautiful. I didn't even think the old Cylons and their "by your command" was too cheezy.

Overall, though, I didn't think it was quite explanatory enough, and it was a bit too soft. The story lingered so much on the interplay between its four main female characters that it started to feel like the Ship That Estrogen Built. Furthermore, Cain playing with her oversized pocket knife, which heretofore had no meaning or use, wasn't menacing or significant enough to be the inspiration for the title.  

If their goal was to humanize Cain and provide understanding as to how things devolved on the Pegasus, ok, but each major point of horror as recounted prior to now--the XO's shooting, the Scylla massacre,Gina's torture--was not nearly as clear as it should have been to accomplish that goal. It's one thing to show "what really happened" versus our sensationalized understanding from the mouth of a drunken XO. It's another thing to blunt the horrors almost entirely and decline to show the rest.

1. The XO Shooting - She's just decided to engage the enemy; the XO resists; without deliberation, she takes his pistol and shoots him. At no point do we see her noting a rising doubt in her crew, which would demand a definitive action. She doesn't seem unsure. She doesn't think about it. They don't have an antagonistic relationship. Essentially, there is no reason or warning. We're left to reason with ourselves, desperate times... one action and the crew will follow her without question... all those things could have been indicated through other means, like her glancing around to see other crew starting to question their duities. The way this went down made less sense than either her being a straight-up hardass or her making an offensive strike. It was just random and over the top.

2. The Scylla Massacre - We revisit in the end that it was Shaw that took the first shot and killed a civilian to put down the unrest. But in that take, it seems she is the only person to take out her gun and shoots the woman. No one even knows who those people are related to yet, because they aren't as yet "lined up against the bulkhead." No one behind her makes a move, and the XO is still bewildered. Yet the deck is covered in dead civilians. I can follow their logic in making a statement and shooting one person; what I can't figure out is how that turned into a mass execution. And again, it wouldn't have killed someone to include a minor reasoning thought from Cain: "If we take on these new civilians, we won't be able to feed ourselves. We'll have to leave them. Strip the ships."

3. Gina's Torture - Thanks to the Quizno's Obvious Statement commercials, we know Cain was a scorned, betrayed woman. It's obvious she feels manipulated and the way she instructs Thorne to test "its" limits is understandable--it isn't human, and she's pretty sure it can be cracked by using its emotional vulnerabilities. Fine. She probably even knows Thorne is an inhuman bastard and is doing him a favor by giving his sadism an outlet. That kind of thing would be hard to hide on a ship. How that turns into a Please Disturb sign where all the men of the ship are lined up to take a turn with her was completely glossed over. The writers said they deliberately didn't go there after horrifying everyone with Thorne and Boomer earlier, but unleashing one guy on a prisoner is a completely different thing from encouraging an environment of inhumanity on an entire Battlestar.

Maybe that's what it degenerated to in the ensuing time before they met up again with the Galactica, but where we left Cain is still solidly in her flowing-locked, misty-eyed days of playing with knives. 

Overall, it just packed very little punch, other than what we've mostly already seen thanks to the minisodes as to the origins of the hybrids. I ended up caring less about her and wondering more about them...

* So the hybrids... they're all originally human?
* Are they like the Navigators in Dune that can see and touch time, and this is why they know all about everyone?
* Or are they just lunatics?
* How did they make the leap from Hybrids to Humlons? Because they're still using Hybrids to fly the ships.
* The new Cylons... they're not cloned? They are cloned? They're original designs?
* Why do they need more genetic material?
* Whatever the answer is for that, why is it important if they finally learned how to procreate?
* After all those years, are they seriously still trying to figure out the anatomy of the forearm?

The problem is, the Hybrids felt more like a distraction device at the end of a long unsatisfactorially answered question, so will those ever be answered... And if so, will it be in BSG: Bubble Bath?

ETA: And one more thing regarding Lee giving the order for Kara to stay behind and blow the nuke--was that supposed to be the beginning of her problem with him, leading to an open door for him to pursue Dee seriously? They were way too cavalier with each other when she returned, even teasing. Rang pretty false for me.

1. When I spend 15 minutes explaining all that I have to do/cook/clean tonight prior to the meal that will be served at noon tomorrow (noon?!), that is not an opening for you to complain about how you've been doing those very things all day and guilt-trippily ask if I wouldn't like to do something this evening so you can get out of the house. Hello? One of the downsides to family is that everyone takes my "no" as a speedbump, temporarily slowing them down until they get what they want.

2. Though I'm not hosting Thanksgiving itself, I am hosting a Leftovers Dinner on Friday (not just reheating, but using them in other things) to which my grandparents are coming. They don't like to host this holiday, since they do Christmas, so each year they decide which child they'll visit and just go there. Unfortunately without notice. Personally, I think it's cool, seeing as how we all have plenty of food. Frankly,  I think we should just serve the kick-assingest meal, so that they always want to be at our house, and then we win Thanksgiving. My mother disagrees, and is in a tizzy because they were heading our way. Ah, family drama. So anyway, my apartment gets to either be the Neutral Zone or Ground Zero, depending on how it goes down.

3. I took out the sweet potatoes to peel and cube. I JUST bought them a couple of days ago, and what do I see. Mold stringing from one of them like Rip Van Winkle's beard, threatening the other spuds. It was very reminiscent of that episode of Swiss Family Robinson when a meteor crashes on the island and starts growing stinging hairs everywhere and killing the goats and whatnot, a reference which I use frequently, belying the childhood trauma it inspired. Fortunately I did peek out from behind the couch to see that water killed the poisonous space strands, so I doused the infected yam with hot water and, voila, it is cured.*

*For those of you questioning my cooking safety skills, it is only growing on the skin, which is coming off anyway.

32. My favorite animal

Remember this little guy from my zoo photography expedition? I logged in to Flickr today to upload a few new pics, clicked on "latest comments," and was floored by a string of new visitors. Apparently he'd wound his way onto Cute Overload when I wasn't looking and the picture now has almost 5,000 views!

I'm gobsmacked.

Here's the entry on Cute Overload. I love the title they gave it.

Today centered around filing for travel reimbursement and learning about the new reimbursement system. It is just as exciting as it seems. Except, here's the thing. It's so "convenient" that you have to do the following:

1. Attend an auditorium orientation
2. Take 10 online classes centered on various aspects of the system
3. Attend a 2-hour classroom event

Anything that takes that long to learn can only lead to evil things.

Sometimes I think these systems are designed by the prisoners at Gitmo, who are taking out their revenge on the Capitalistic Satan via applications that are as tortuous as possible. The only thing I can see this doing is sifting out people who are currently doing their own reports and settling it squarely on the secretaries or anyone they consider to be secretary-like. I'm already used to it, thanks to our ordering system which adapts less intuitively every 5 seconds and endangers my soul each time I use it, due to the amount of cursing it inspires.

In fact, I think that is part of the talley at the bottom: Items, Amount, Total, Years Incurred in Purgatory. It is now a subpoint under Wrath as Deadly Sin 7A. 

Apparently this NEW system is so helpful that you have to fill out a new report for each individual receipt and tip. Also, according to our lovely presenter, the system is magical, because it places credit card swipers in all taxis, so we will never have to dirty our hands with out-of-pocket cash again.

Yeah, I don't know where SHE takes taxis, but that isn't true for any city I travel in. 

Anyway, gotta go for now and order some office Christmas cards. If I'm not back in an hour, see you in hell.

No? Just me?
